content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle - All previous issues sorted.
All information is relevant and sufficient test cases.

Potential statement improvement - Simple comment saying timestamp 1 is 0:00 - 1:00 or something similar.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle.
Tests did incorporate a lot of traps that could be made during string/array manipulation.
i guess its a valid problem

One final clarification from me, with regards to points being scored scored at XX:01.

Given two team A and B, if team A scores in 1st timestamp (0:01), they will only be leading 59 seconds at 1:00 (0:00 - 0:01 would be a tie). So if the match was 80:00, they would be leading 79:59.

I know it's not tested in the test cases but in general just making sure that it's fine.

Input section 'Line 2' - Consider using bold text to highlight the key points.
Also I would put the 'Timestamps are integers' in the constraints section instead of input.

I think any mention that a conversion happens after a try is unnecessary - Unless there was an 'Invalid Timestamps' or equivalent output it would be needed, but since there isn't I don't think it needs to be mentioned.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it's a nice puzzle... i was little confused about the "conversion" after the "try".. it's a rule that it doesn't affect the puzzle code solution....also, looks like you cover all possible test cases

You state that "a conversion after a try is worth 2 points" but your code awards 2 points for all conversions regardless of a try for the same team happening on the last score.

You have a few tests where both teams score at the same time, should that be possible?

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Nice puzzle idea.

This will be good, but I think I've found a few edits that would improve it.

The input format for [[scores1|2]] is a bit complicated and not explained very well. The first line "a string scores1, a sorted list of timestamps when the first team scored a try, converted a try, scored a penalty and scored a dropped goal", makes it sound like it's one list.
Really, it's four space-separated lists of integer timestamps, with the four lists separated by commas. Maybe you could write:

a string [[scores1]], 4 lists of space-separated timestamps for when the first team scored: a try, a conversion, a penalty, and a dropped goal. The four lists are comma-separated and any of them may be empty. Timestamps are integers.

Also, I'm pretty sure your solution and answers are counting the minutes wrong according to your statement. Your code goes from t = 1 to 80, but because you increase the scores at the start of your loop and then immediately add minutes to the adv. time of whoever is leading, you are essentially 'paying them in advance' for the minute that has just started, But that means that by starting with t += 1 at the start of your loop that you've skipped the minute from 0:00-> 1:00 and are instead including the minute from 80:00->81:00.

You can see this most clearly in the Scotland Romania test, since and Scotland first takes the lead at 9:00 and then never loses it. This means there were only 9 minutes out of 80 where it didn't have the advantage, so they should have 71 minutes of advantage time, but your solution gives 72 instead.

If you fix these issues, I'd be happy to approve.

Goal
* Suggest to change "When both team have the same score, neither has the advantage." to "A team has the advantage when its score is greater than the other team's." I think the latter is more direct and easier to understand.

Input
* Line 2
(a) Please change "team A" to "the first team" to avoid confusion (as some cases actually have "Team A" or "A Team" as input).

(b) Suggest to change "[[scores_a]]" to "[[scores1]]".

(c) "and an apostrophe"…?

(d) I think it's easier to understand if you mention "The four categories are comma-separated and any of them may be empty." before you mention "Timestamps consist of space-separated integers."

* Line 3: (similar logic to what is mentioned for Line 2)
(a) Suggest to change "[[scores_b]]" to "[[scores2]]".

(b) Please change "same for team B" to "a sorted list of timestamps for the second team in the same format as that for the first team".

Output
* "score": Do you mean "final score"?

* Suggest to rewrite the whole section as follows:
<<Line 1:>> [[data]] for the first team
<<Line 2:>> [[data]] for the second team
[[data]] is in the format of [[name]]{{:}} [[score]] [[time]] where:
[[name]] is the team's name
[[score]] is the team's final score
[[time]] is the time in minutes during which the team has an advantage

Stub generator
* Suggest to change "[[scoresA]]" to "[[scores1]]".

* Suggest to change "[[scoresB]]" to "[[scores2]]".

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

Thank you for your ideas. I fixed the statement for the input format, it's much clearer now.
When a goal is scored at the first second of a match (00:01), it's in the first minute (1'), this is why I chose to write "Consider that the points are scored at the first second of a minute." That means that if a team scores during the first minute, they have the advantage during this minute. It can be a bit weird because during 1', the timer is 00:xx, but I don't think this is a big problem.
That's why in the Scotland Romania test, they have the lead during 72 minutes, because they scored it during 9', at 08:00
Do you think this is too complicated and should be changed ?

A conversion can only happen after a try, and it always does in the testcases. I should make it clearer.
I don't think scoring at the same time is a problem in this puzzle, it can easily be handled, in a real game, both teams could score in the same minute.
Thank you, I updated the statement, and removed the "conversion after a try" explanation since it doesn't need to be checked.

The first second is from 0:00:00 to 0:00:01, don't you think the explanation makes it clear enough that a goal scored in a minute gives the advantage to the team during that minute ? I assumed it was not necessary since that would mean go to another level of precision (everything else is in minutes).
I updated the sentence from "at the first second of a minute" to "at the beginning of a minute". Tell me if it's better for you.

Nice, the explanations of the inputs are much better now.

As for the minutes, I think either way can be explained/justified, but when you say they are 'timestamps', it's natural for clashers to think that '3' means during the minute from 3:00 to 3:59, rather than the '3rd minute' (2:00 to 2:59). If you want to keep it that way, I think it's best not to call them timestamps or at least add an explanation that a timestamp of 'n' means you should consider the point was scored at (n-1):00.  But personally, I think it would be clearer the other way. But as long as you add a clear explanation then either can work.
Any plan to add a cover picture?
